messageBody:
Thanks for the idea; looks like System.setOut() will do just what I want.

But your answer raises another question; why do I have to 'reset' the Printstream for each test; I thought all the tests were independent and that there wouldn't be leftover state from prior test to confund a later test.

Could this be related to a problem I had with the test suite with several similar test that wrote to a file: the output file of th 2nd tests contained the output of the 1st and 2nd test, the ouput of the 3rd contained the output of the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd tests. I ended up having to write separate classes to get all the tests done.

Thanks again,

Cheers,

jim


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Bob Runstein" <rrunstein@...> wrote:
>
>
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "cant_jim" <jimcant@> wrote:
> >
> > How can I capture the standard output of test? I need to check that
> the messages from the class I'm testing are correct. For example if my
> class class calls a parser that print "invalid input at line xx" when it
> fails, I want to be able go catch that output and compare it to the
> expected value. If it could be directed to a file on a per-test basis, I
> could do a diff to check it.
> >
> > Any suggestions would be appreciated.
> >
> > Thanks,
> >
> > Jim Cant
> >
>
> You can override the default behavior of System.out.println() using
> System.setOut(PrintStream). Subclass PrintStream and override the print
> methods to log to a file that you can specify. Even better, add a
> StringBuilder member with setter and getter to the PrintStream and
> override the print methods to append to that. Your test can do
> assertEquals on your expected value and the toString value of the
> StringBuilder. Don't forget to reset the PrintStream before each test.
>
